III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program Statement
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staffs are providing two youth with nicotine vapes.
1

Additional Allegations received on 4/28/25:
Youth A resides at Vista Maria Home for Girls, where Staff 1 and
Staff 2 and are staff members. It is alleged that Staff 2 was
bringing vapes to Youth A and other children at Vista Maria. Youth
A admitted that she lied to CPS about who was bringing the vapes
previously. It was not Staff 4 who did it. Staff 4 was placed on
leave. Staff 2 is under investigation. On the days this was alleged
to have happened, Staff 2 was not working or on campus. There is
concern that these allegations are false due to that fact. The time
frame does not match the time that the vapes were found and the
vapes that were found were not brought to the facility by any staff
members.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was interviewed via telephone on 4/28/2025 and
reported they had no additional information.
All the following interviews were conducted face to face at
the facility on 5/1/25 in collaboration with MDHHS worker.
Youth A reported Staff 1 and Staff 2 have given her vape pens
identified as the Breeze Brand. Youth A reported receiving the
vape pen shortly after arriving at the facility. Youth A reported
asking Staff 2 for a vape and Staff 2 gave her one. Additionally,
Youth A reported Staff 2 had previously given her and Youth B
edibles. Youth A reported Staff 1 allowed her to use a vape pen
several times, with the most recent incident being on Friday,
4/25/25. She recalled Staff 1 offering it to her unprompted. Youth
A reported using the vape in the bathroom and returned it to Staff
1 afterward. Youth A reported Staff 1 allowed her to use the vape
in her room after confronting Staff 1 about allowing Youth B to use
the vape. Youth A was unsure whether Staff 1 had shared vapes
with other youth. Youth A observed Youth B appearing to be
under the influence of Xanax during a group session. Youth A
stated Youth B mentioned receiving the Xanax from an
unidentified staff in exchange for her medication, though Youth A
did not ask for the staff's name.
Youth B reported she had previously been caught with a vape
pen by staff a few weeks ago during the timeframe of 4/4/25-
4/23/25. Youth B reported she received a vape from Youth A who
had hidden it on campus after returning from a home pass. Youth
B reported Youth A hid the vape on campus, and she retrieved it
during an unapproved walk and brought it back to the building.
Youth B reported she has not seen any staff distribute vapes or
2

edibles to other youth. Youth B reported she has never received
vapes or edibles from any staff, except from Staff 4, who gave
Youth B edibles about a month ago, shortly after being placed
(SIR #2025SIC0000529). Youth B said she has no concerns
regarding Staff 1 and Staff 2.
Youth B denied receiving a vape from any staff in exchange for
her Xanax. Youth B reported she has never exchanged her
prescribed medication with staff for anything else and has not
received any medication from staff she wasn’t supposed to
receive. Youth B reported she shared some of her Adderall with
Youth A before. Youth B reported there were not staff around
when this occurred and was unable to provide the dates for when
this occurred. Youth B reported when she receives medication,
staff check her mouth by requesting her to open her mouth and lift
her tongue. Youth B reported she was able to position her
medication in her mouth where even when she opened her mouth
and lifted her tongue, staff were unable to see it. Youth B noted
other residents have learned how to hide their medication in their
mouths instead of swallowing it, but did not remember which youth
did this, and declined to discuss further.
Consumer’s Rights Advocate reported youth frequently leave
their building to go on unapproved walks around the campus. It
was reported if Youth B picked up a vape on campus grounds, it
was during a time where she was unsupervised due to being
AWOL. Consumer’s Rights Advocate reported Youth B was not
approved for any campus walks during the month of April due to
Youth B’s behavior. Consumer’s Rights Advocate addressed
recent allegations involving Staff 4, who was suspended after
being accused of providing vapes to youth. The investigation
(SIR# 2025SIC0000529) found no evidence, and the case was
closed. Staff 4 has since returned to work. Consumer’s Rights
Advocate confirmed awareness of the facility’s smoking policies,
noting staff must keep vapes in their vehicles and are prohibited
from giving any paraphernalia to youth.
Youth C reported being at Vista Maria for approximately eight
months. Youth C reported no concerns with Staff 1 or Staff 2,
describing both as kind. However, Youth C reported Staff 1 was
approached by Youth A who asked Staff 1 to bring in vapes and
edibles. Youth C reported Staff 1 once offered to bring Youth A
and Youth C edibles, but later changed her mind and did not
follow through. Youth C also reported Staff 1 offered to bring her
vapes, but Youth C declined. Youth C reported being unsure
whether a vape was given to Youth A. Youth C reported hearing
Youth A was recently caught with a vape and said Youth A had
previously claimed Staff 1 provided her with both vapes and
3

edibles. Youth C denied seeing Staff 1, Staff 2 or any other staff
bring in contraband or provide contraband to any youth.
Youth D reported being at Vista Maria for about a year. Youth D
reported Youth A has had vapes on multiple occasions and
believes Youth A brings them in after returning from off-campus
visits. Youth D stated she does not believe staff are providing
vapes and emphasized Youth A has a habit of being dishonest,
particularly about staff. She shared Youth A has given her vapes
in the past, but no staff have ever done so. Youth D did not raise
any concerns about Staff 1 or Staff 2.
Unit Manager was interviewed and reported there are no
concerns regarding Staff 1 or Staff 2 in terms of their behavior or
interactions with youth. Unit Manger noted any prior disciplinary
action involving Staff 1 and Staff 2 was related solely to
attendance issues. Unit Manager reported although there have
been reports involving Youth A and vape use, Unit Supervisor
denied hearing or witnessing staff provide vapes to youth. She
emphasized staff are prohibited from smoking or bringing any
paraphernalia into the building. Those who wish to smoke must do
so off-campus, across the street. Additionally, staff are required to
leave any vapes, cigarettes, or related items in their personal
vehicles.
Staff 1 reported she has never brought any items, including
vapes or edibles, for youth. Staff 1 reported she has never offered
Youth A, Youth B or any other youth at Vista Maria a vape or
edible and has never brought any into the facility either. Staff 1
reported being aware Youth B ran away and later returned with a
vape pen reportedly found on campus. Staff 1 reported Youth A
frequently asked her to bring a vape pen, but Staff 1 reported
consistently turning Youth A down. Staff 1 recalled a recent
incident where Youth A became upset after Staff 1 denied Youth A
a vape pen she wanted for an upcoming home pass. Staff 1
affirmed she has never seen any staff at work in possession of
vapes or edibles. Staff 1 also expressed full awareness of facility
policy, noting staff are strictly prohibited from having vapes or
related paraphernalia on campus.
Staff 2 reported being aware of Youth A’s claims she had supplied
Youth A with a vape pen and edibles. Staff 2 reported filing an
incident report about the false accusations of providing youth with
edibles or vapes. She noted a vape pen was recently confiscated
from Youth A, but Staff 2 clarified she was not on duty on the days
the items were found. Staff 2 firmly denied ever bringing vape
pens or edibles into the facility or providing them to Youth A or any
4

other youth at Vista Maria. Staff 2 stated she has never seen any
staff with such items on campus. Staff 2 reported Youth A seemed
to know confiscated vapes were kept in a shared supervisor office.
She recounted an incident in which Youth A asked her to retrieve
a vape pen from the shared supervisor office. Staff 2 said she
refused and believes this may have prompted Youth A to retaliate
by making false accusations.
Clinical Supervisor reported she has heard youth have vapes,
however she has never seen a youth with a vape and she has
never had any concerns staff are providing vapes or edibles to
youth.
Staff 3 reported he has never witnessed staff bring in vapes or
edibles for youth.
Supervisor was interviewed regarding the additional allegation for
this investigation. Supervisor reported no direct knowledge of Staff
1 possessing or giving vape pens or edibles to youth. Supervisor
clarified on the day Youth A claimed Staff 4 provided her with
edibles, Staff 4 was not on duty. Subsequently, Youth A alleged
Staff 1 was the one who provided the vapes. Supervisor reported
never witnessing Staff 1 or Staff 2 with vapes or edibles.
Additionally, there have been no previous concerns or reports
suggesting either staff gave vape pens or edibles to Youth A or
Youth B.
Documents Reviewed:
• POL 006-017 Client Privacy: Any personal items
confiscated or retrieved during a room search will be
secured with the youth’s personal items in storage or in the
unit locked cabinet or safe, depending on the item
retrieved.
• Procedures for Personal/Body Searches: These
searches are conducted when there is a suspicion of a
youth having contraband.
• POL 022-114 Employee Behavior: Prohibited behavior of
Vista Maria employees: Violation of Vista Maria
Drug/alcohol-free workplace policy, including, but not
limited to selling, purchasing, dispensing, or possessing
alcohol or illegal drugs on Vista Maria’s premises.
• POL-022-406 Staff and Client Interaction: Staff should
never accept purchased or monetary gifts/items from
clients. All gifts/items for clients will be provided via the
Vista Boutique or purchased with authorized Vista Maria
funds. Any exceptions to the above must be approved by
the Building Manager.
5

• Incident Report dated 4/23/25 states Youth A gave
conflicting information to another staff, stating she received
the vapes sometime during the week of April 13–19, 2025.
Youth A did not disclose which Staff provided the edibles.
According to the report, Youth A reported she was not
sober from Nicotine and the last time she had Nicotine was
on last week Tuesday or Wednesday from 4/23/25. Youth A
declined to disclose which staff was/were involved or the
shift in which this occurred.
• Incident report dated 4/25/25 is consistent with Youth A’s
interview. This incident report documents Youth A’s
disclosure about Staff 1 providing her the vape.
• Vista Maria Staff Schedule:
o 4/22/25 - This document indicates Staff 1 in call off
status for the 7am-3pm shift.
o 4/23/25 - Staff 1 worked on this day 7:30am-3:30pm.
o 4/24/25 - Staff 1 was listed a floater from 8am-4pm.
o 4/25/25 - Staff 1 was listed on the schedule for 7am-
3pm shift. Staff 2 is listed on the schedule for 7am-
3pm.
• Staff 1’s personnel file did not contain any disciplinary
records. Staff 1 completed Employee Training Guide on
10/28/24, and Client Onboarding training on 10/17/24.
• Staff 2’s personnel file contained one disciplinary record
unrelated to this investigation. Staff 2 completed Employee
Training Guide on 10/28/24.
Analysis The agency was found to be in compliance, as per interviews
conducted and documentation reviewed, there was insufficient
information to substantiate a rule violation.
Both Staff 1 and Staff 2 denied giving any youth vapes or edibles.
Multiple staff and youth at the facility were interviewed and all but
Youth A confirmed they did not witness Staff 1 or Staff 2 providing
contraband to youth.
Youth B reported she received a vape from Youth A who had
hidden it on campus after returning from a home pass. Youth B
reported Staff 1 and Staff 2 did not provide her with vapes or
edibles. Youth B further reported the vapes and edibles received
came from Staff 4, not Staff 1 or Staff 2. Staff 4 was placed on
administrative leave from 4/4/25-4/23/25. This was addressed in
investigation SIR #2025SIC0000529, which found no rule
violations, and the employee was permitted to return to work.
There were also inconsistencies in the reported dates on which
the vapes and edibles were allegedly received. Youth A claimed
she was given the vapes on April 25, 2025, while Youth B stated
6

she received them the week prior. However, according to the
incident report, Youth A gave conflicting information to another
staff, stating she received the vapes sometime during the week of
April 13–19, 2025.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
• The facility should explore their medication passing policy
and procedure to ensure it’s sufficient in avoiding youth
hiding their medications in their mouth.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules.
